definition: Wang Chong (27-97), rationalist and critical philosopher
surname Wang
king or monarch/best or strongest of its type/grand/great
to rule/to reign over
to fill/to satisfy/to fulfill/to act in place of/substitute/sufficient/full

sentences.english: Wang Chong paid a great attention to scholars' social mission.
sentences.chinese: 王充对士人的使命有着强烈的关注。

sentences.english: Wang Chonglu is one of the most representative of prose writers in contemporary China.
sentences.chinese: 在当代中国散文作家中，王充闾是较有代表性的一位。

sentences.english: The second part is the view of historical materialism on The destiny theory of Wang Ch'ung.
sentences.chinese: 第二部分是历史唯物主义视域下的王充“命论”。

sentences.english: Wang Chong is an outstanding ideologist of atheism in the East Han dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 王充是东汉杰出的无神论思想家。

definition: Ban Gu (32-92), Eastern Han dynasty historian, wrote the Dynastic History of Western Han 漢書|汉书
Dong Zhongshu (179-104 BC), philosopher influential in establishing Confucianism as the established system of values of former Han dynasty
Xun Zi or Hsun Tzu (c. 310-237 BC), Confucian philosopher and author of On learning 勸學|劝学
Kong Yingda (574-648), Confucian scholar
Zheng Xuan (127-200), late Han scholar
Yang Xiong (53 BC-18 AD), scholar, poet and lexicographer, author of the first Chinese dialect dictionary 方言[Fang1 yan2]
Zou Yan (305-240 BC), founder of the School of Yin-Yang of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Luxuriant Dew of the Spring and Autumn Annals, ideological tract by Han dynasty political philosopher Dong Zhongshu 董仲舒[Dong3 Zhong4 shu1]
Han Feizi, book of Legalist Philosophy authored by Han Fei 韓非|韩非[Han2 Fei1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Sima Qian (145-86 BC), Han Dynasty historian, author of Records of the Grand Historian 史記|史记[Shi3 ji4], known as the father of Chinese historiography
Mencius (c. 372-c. 289 BC), Confucian philosopher second only to Confucius/book of the same name, one of the classics of Confucianism
History of the Former Han Dynasty, second of the 24 dynastic histories 二十四史[Er4 shi2 si4 Shi3], composed by Ban Gu 班固[Ban1 Gu4] in 82 during Eastern Han (later Han), 100 scrolls
Wei Boyang (c. 100-170), Chinese author and alchemist
Liu Xiang (77-6 BC), Han Dynasty scholar and author
Wang Bi (226-249), Chinese neo-Daoist philosopher
miscellany of writing from the Western Han (aka Former Han)
